investigations.title: CR Investigation 1 Extending the Rational Number System

text:
Problem 1.1 The Game of Going Positive: Using Positive and Negative Numbers

This Problem builds on students’ intuitions about negative numbers and asks questions that may be represented by addition or related subtraction expressions. This is a good opportunity for you to learn what your students already know about integers and ways of operating on them. In the Initial Challenge students will look at how groups of students could attain certain positive or negative score in The Game of Going Positive. The What If Situations will ease students into looking at number sentences to represent the scores changing in the game.

NWDYK

What strategies can you use for combining positive and negative integers to find a total value?

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Introduction/Exploration/Analysis
Key Terms
Materials

Pacing

1 Day

Groups

Think-Pair-Share

A #1-2

C #13-14

E #20

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

Teacher Moves: Delay the Question

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

Explore extending the number line to include negative integers and rational values. Have students label the integer points from -10 to 10 on the number line. Students should then locate some fractional and decimal values between the integers. Have students draw lines to connect some pairs of numbers to show opposites on their number lines.

Show the picture of the Going Positive game board. Ask them to think about what this unit/problem might be about. Using the Going Positive PowerPoint game playing a few questions can help¬ students understand how it is played.

Implementation Note: In Investigation 2, students will develop algorithms for addition and subtraction of integers. To prepare for this collect number sentences that they use in Investigation 1 (see extended Launch-Explore-Summarize)

Teacher Moves: Portrayal

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Discuss the Going Positive game as described in the student edition.

Suggested Questions

  • What happens when a team gets a question incorrect? Correct? (When a question is answered incorrectly a team loses points and when answered correctly they gain points)
  • Could a team ever have negative points? (yes)

Implementation Note: You may want to have a brief conversation after the Initial Challenge to discuss number sentences before having the students work on the What If section. Don’t force formal ways of writing number sentences at this time.

EXPLORE

Teacher Moves: Agency, Identity, Ownership

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

Suggested Questions

  • Where is this number in relation to zero?
  • Would a number line be helpful?
  • Is the team earning points or losing points?
  • How can you indicate that the team is earning or losing points in your equation?

Some students can be challenged to delve further into the content. Below are some additional questions you can ask about the Going Positive game:

  • What is the fewest number of questions that each team could have answered to get their current score?
  • If the Rocket Scientists reached their score after answering ten questions, what is a possible sequence of questions they could have answered? Is that the only sequence?
  • If the Rocket Scientists get the next question wrong, will they have a positive or negative score?

Implementation Note: You may need to use Situation D at a later time in the unit. If your students need more time to experiment with the positive and negative numbers. If using equations feels like a big leap at this time, use this when you feel your students are ready.

Teacher Moves: Language

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

Answers will be informal and provide an opportunity to assess students understand. Listen for how students are talking about the impact on the score when a team gets a question incorrect in the Going Positive Game. Listen for how they describe taking away points or adding on a negative score. Listen for ways that students will use zero as an “anchor point” for finding the final score.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Compare Thinking

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

For the Initial Challenge ask the class how they found the difference between the teams’ scores. Have several pairs share their number sentences for the Initial Challenge. There are many ways each team could have arrived at their score. Take note of whether or not students offer different orders of scoring as different solutions.

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

Suggested Questions

  • What strategy did you use to determine each team’s new score after the sequence of points?
  • How did you determine the difference in points for each pair of teams?
  • What would the number sentence be that reflects your reasoning?

For What If Situation A, ask students to explain how they found each team’s final score.

This is a good opportunity to gather some formative assessment data on what the students understand about addition and subtraction relationships and about additive inverses.

As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: CR 1.2 Falling and Rising Temperatures in Montana
problems.subtitle: Using a Number Line

text:
Problem 1.2 Falling and Rising Temperatures in Montana: Using a Number Line

Students write number sentences and sketch number lines, both vertical and horizontal, to compare temperatures. In the Initial Challenge students encounter extreme temperature changes in Montana and determine use number lines to understand the change. The What If Situations offer more opportunities for students to make sense of changing temperatures using number lines and number sentences. Students use informal arithmetic reasoning to connect direction and distance to the number line, and then represent their reasoning with number sentences.

NWDYK

Describe a strategy for finding the change in temperature when given a beginning and ending temperatures. How can you represent this difference on a number line?

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Exploration/Analysis
Key Terms

Materials

Learning Aid: Number Lines

Learning Aid: 1.2 Situation C Matching Change, Number Lines, and Equations

Pacing

1 Day

Groups

2-3 students

A #3-7

C #15-17

E #21

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

Review the vocabulary of rational numbers, opposites and negative rational numbers that are in the introduction of the Student Edition. Discuss how to represent a temperature change with a number line and an equation using the question in the introduction.

Engage students in a discussion of temperature changes they may have experienced.

Note: In Investigation 2, students will develop algorithms for addition and subtraction of integers. To prepare for this collect number sentences that they use in Investigation 1 (see extended Launch-Explore-Summarize)

Teacher Moves: Language

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Suggested Questions

  • You can think of a thermometer as a vertical number line. On a thermometer, where are the positive numbers located in relation to 0℉?
  • Where are the negative numbers located in relation to 0℉?
  • Suppose the temperature is +5℉. Where is the +5℉ located on this vertical number line in relation to 0℉? Repeat with -5℉.
  • How is the horizontal number line different from vertical thermometers? How is it the same?

Help students understand that these changes have both distance and direction.

EXPLORE

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

As you circulate, have students explain how they are determining their solutions. Encourage students to use sketches on number lines to show their thinking and to write addition and/or subtraction number sentences to describe their work.

Suggested Questions

  • What is the starting temperature? (Answers will vary)
  • What is the ending temperature? (Answers will vary)
  • Is the temperature increasing or decreasing? (Answers will vary)
  • How can your number line express this change?

Teacher Moves: Portrayal

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

As you are circulating during the explore look for how students are making sense of using number lines to show change. Are students making sense of positive and negative direction? Are students making sense of positive and negative values for temperature? Look for how students are making sense of number sentences representing change in temperature.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Portrayal, Language

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

Have students demonstrate and explain their solutions. Take time to consider the number sentences that can be written to describe the actions on the number lines.

Suggested Questions

  • When you wrote addition sentences, what did the first number represent?
  • What did the second number represent?
  • What did the sum represent?
  • When you wrote subtraction sentences, what did the numbers represent?

Teacher Moves: Connect, Extend, Challenge

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

Suggested Questions

  • What did the arrow represent?
  • How does the number line represent each number sentence?
  • How did you decide which number sentence matched with which number line?
  • What aspects of these new ideas are challenging your thinking?

As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

Problem 1.3 The Game of Zero: Using a Chip Model

Students model addition and subtraction on chip-board displays. Students explore relationships between addition and subtraction as well. One chip color indicates positive values, and the other chip color indicates negative values. In the Initial Challenge students are introduced to the chip board model and using red and black chips to represent positive and negative numbers. What If Situations A-C give students opportunities to experiment with the chipboard model and using red and black chips to put zeroes on the board as needed. In What If Situation D student will play The Game of Zero.

NWDYK

How can you use a chip board to represent addition and subtraction of integers?

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Exploration/Analysis
Key Terms

Materials

Learning Aid: Small Chipboards OR digital drawing tools with chip stamps

Learning Aid 1.3A: Cards

Learning Aid 1.3B: Recording Sheet

2 color chips OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Number cubes

Pacing

2 days

Groups

2-3 students

A #8-12

C #18-19

E #22

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

Discuss the context of describing finances as “in the black” or “in the red.” Check to see if your students have ever heard these terms used and in what context.

Note: In Investigation 2, students will develop algorithms for addition and subtraction of integers. To prepare for this collect number sentences that they use in Investigation 1 (see extended Launch-Explore-Summarize)

Teacher Moves: Time

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Introduce chipboards and how to use them. Have students represent 5 with 5 black chips. Repeat with -5 and 5 red chips. Go back to +5 and ask if there is any way to represent +5 with red and black chips?

Discuss the situation in the introduction of the student edition about Tate owing his sister money. Display Julia’s chipboard that is in the Student Edition. Give partners a set of two-color chips. Launch students into the Problem to investigate chipboard situations.

Note: This problem may take 2 days for students to fully explore the ideas and to discuss their findings as a whole class. Giving them this time to investigate creating zeroes will be beneficial when they use it to create algorithms in Investigation 2.

EXPLORE

Teacher Moves: Problem Solving Environment

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

As you circulate, have students explain how they are determining their solutions. Encourage students to use chips and the chip board to show their thinking. Have them write addition and/or subtraction number sentences to describe their work.

Suggested Questions

  • Can you use chips to Model Beatrice and/or Mo’s ideas in Situation B?
  • After Isabella and Nick’s moves there is the same total value, but the combination of chips is different. Why is this true?
  • What happens to the total value on the chip board if you add 1 black chip and 1 red chip?
  • How can you use this information to help you subtract 2 black chips?

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

Look for the patterns that students notice when working on the different situations. Take note of how students dealt with situations when there weren’t enough chips on their board to subtract. Help students to verbalize how the use of zeroes helps them.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Compare Thinking

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

Have students demonstrate and explain their solutions using chips. Take time to discuss the number sentences that can be written to describe the actions. As an extension, encourage students to find other number sentences that show the same total value.

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

Suggested Questions

  • Do you have any What if questions?
  • How does Julia’s chip board relate to her expression?
  • What is some other ways Julia can show a total value of -2?
  • What is some ways Julia can show a total value of 0?
  • What are some groups of red chips and black chips that Julia can add to her board that will not change her total value?

For What If Situation A, have students demonstrate how to show the same idea with the number line.

Have students turn to another partner group and share their real-life situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0 for What If Situation B. Bring to the whole class any situations that are causing disagreements to decide if they are correct.

  • When playing the Game of Zero what were some moves that you made?

As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

investigations.title: CR Investigation 2 Adding and Subtracting Rational Numbers

problems.title: CR 2.1 Extending Addition of Rational Numbers

text:
Problem 2.1 Extending Addition of Rational Numbers

Students are introduced to the idea of an algorithm and challenged to develop an algorithm for addition of rational numbers. The Initial Challenge has students look back over their work in Investigation 1 to look for patterns when adding integers. The What If Situations give students experiences to refine an algorithm for adding integers.

NWDYK

Describe an algorithm for adding rational numbers. How does this compare to your algorithm for adding whole numbers?

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Analysis/Synthesis

Key Terms

Additive Inverse

Additive Identity

Materials

Learning Aid: Number Lines

Learning Aid: Chip Boards OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Two color chips OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Pacing

1 Day

Groups

2 students

A #1-3

C #13

E #18-19

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

Introduce the vocabulary of Additive Inverse and Additive Identity in the student edition.

Suggested Questions

  • How have we found additive inverses helpful so far?
  • Can you think of any other time that we operate on a number and it keeps its identity?
  • How have we found additive identity helpful so far?
  • How can you write a sum of two numbers that results in a sum of -5?

Teacher Moves: Make Predictions

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Students should be comfortable with using number lines and chip board models from their work in Investigation 1. Use the situation in the student edition introduction of the problem with Linda and her friend with video games to review the two models as needed. Tell students they will be using these models in different situations to find patterns to create an algorithm for addition of integers. Have students use the Initial Challenge as a prediction for what they will find as they work through the rest of the problem. If they make changes to their predictions in the Initial Challenge have them jot down what changed their mind.

Note: It may be helpful to debrief their predictions from the Initial Challenge. Remind them that they may change their minds as they continue with the What if when they have more ideas.

EXPLORE

Teacher Moves: Problem Solving Environment

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

Suggest that students use what they know about working with chips and the number line to help them reason as they work through the situations.

Suggested Questions

  • How do you know if the solution will be positive or negative?
  • For What If Situation C: How does the initial number sentence help you?
  • How did you decide when to use a chip model and when to use a number line?

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

Look for ways students are connecting the models to number sentence. Look for how students are generalizing about the sign of the sums. Listen for how students are making sense of the patterns they’ve seen and generalizing this into an algorithm.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Portrayal

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

Have students share their strategies and solutions. Share number lines and chip boards. Connect the models to the symbols in the number sentences. Focus on the generalizations the students find when adding integers.

Teacher Moves: Language

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

As students are sharing their solutions and strategies the questions posed should revolve around getting students to be able to verbalize an algorithm for adding integers.

Suggested Questions

  • How do you solve integer addition problems in which both signs are the same?
  • How do you solve integer addition problems in which the signs of the numbers are different?
  • Which model better represents this situation: the chip model or the number line model? Why do you think this?
  • In What If Situation A, did changing the order if the number change the sum?
  • How did you use the models for What If Situation B?

As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: CR 2.2 Extending Subtraction of Rational Numbers

text:
Problem 2.2 Extending Subtraction of Rational Numbers

In this Problem, students use chip boards and number lines to explore contexts that involve subtraction of rational numbers. The goal is to give students experience in finding and representing differences of rational numbers. In the Initial Challenge students look back at their work from Investigation 1 and draw conclusions about subtracting integers. In the What If Situations they work with expressions and their contexts, students develop an algorithm for computing and representing subtraction with signed numbers.

NWDYK

Describe an algorithm for subtracting rational numbers. How does this compare to your algorithm for subtracting whole numbers?

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Analysis/Synthesis

Key Terms

Commutative Property of Addition

Materials

Learning Aid: Number Lines

Learning Aid: Chip Boards OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Learning Aid 2.2: Solving Equations

Two Color Chips OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Pacing

2 Days

Groups

2 students

A #4-7

C #14-15

E #20

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

By now, students should be comfortable using addition in the context of chips and number lines.

If you have not discussed additive inverses and additive identity, do so now.

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Have students work in groups of two to three to investigate subtraction with integers using chip boards and/or number lines. Their goal will be to develop an algorithm for subtracting integers and to determine that the commutative property does not work for subtraction.

Note: Have a conversation after What If Situation A. This will give students the opportunity to explore subtraction of integers and make some predictions about an algorithm. The second day the students can refine this idea with the rest of the problem.

EXPLORE

Teacher Moves: Time

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

Have students talk through using a number line and make sketches to show their thinking.

Suggest that students use what they know about working with chips and the number line to help them make predictions in the Initial Challenge and What If Situation A. Push students to show evidence of their conclusions.

Models help students make sense of operations like subtraction with integers. These experiences help them get ready to move toward a more abstract understanding of subtraction of integers.

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

Look for ways students are connecting the models to number sentences. Look for how students are generalizing subtracting integers.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Language, Claim, Support, Question

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

Have students share their strategies and solutions. Share number lines and chip boards. Connect the models to the symbols in the number sentences. Focus on the generalizations the students are starting to find when subtracting integers. Discuss the Commutative Property.

Teacher Moves: Problem Solving Environment, Sentence Stem

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

As students are sharing their solutions and strategies the questions posed should revolve around getting students to be able to verbalize an algorithm for subtracting integers.

Suggested Questions

  • How do you know if the difference is positive or negative?
  • Does the Commutative Property apply for subtraction of integers? How do you know?
  • How do you compute subtraction problems in which both signs are the same?
  • How do you compute subtraction problems in which the signs of the numbers are different?

Using the sentence stem “I believe my answer is correct because…” can help focus the discussion.

  • When you are subtracting with integers, must you always think of the operation as subtraction? Why or why not?
  • How did you decide which chip board/number line matched with the equations?

As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

Problem 2.3 Profit or Loss: The +/- Connection

This Problem supports students in synthesizing their thinking about addition and subtraction with integers. In the Initial Challenge students will look at three different fund-raising activities and analyze the profit and loss of each. In the What If Situations students will use fact families, examples, models, equations, and context to solidify their algorithms for adding and subtracting integers.

NWDYK

How are addition and subtraction related?

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Synthesis
Key Terms

Materials

Learning Aid: Number Lines

Learning Aid: Chip Boards OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Two Color Chips OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Pacing

1 Day

Groups

2-3 students

A #8-12

C #16-17

E #21

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

Teacher Moves: Time

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

Since The Game of Going Positive in Problem 1.1 students have been informally thinking about the connection between adding and subtracting with integers. This problem will help students to formalize their thinking about the +/- connection.

Discuss the introduction in the Student Edition on notation. Stress that at this point the vocabulary that we use is very important. It is important to distinguish between “positive versus negative” and “add versus subtract”.

Teacher Moves: Problem Solving Environment, Language

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Bringing back an idea from The Game of Going Positive to illustrate this connection can set the stage.

Discuss the ideas of profit and loss and how they relate to positive and negative numbers.

Describe the situation of a middle school raising money to make improvements to the recreation center.

Note: You may want to divide the class into three groups and have them work on one grade level instead of all three.

You might want to have a brief discussion after the Initial Challenge before having the students look at the What If. They will start to formulate their ideas about the relationship between addition and subtraction here and then strengthen it through the What If situations. Getting a sense of where they are before they attack these situations can be helpful.

EXPLORE

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

Remind students that they can model each equation with a chip board or a number line to try out their ideas.

Suggested Questions

  • In the Initial Challenge, how does the advertising money impact profit or loss?
  • How does the price for purchasing smoothie bars from a distributor/supplies or a car wash/price or to create a digital recording impact profit or loss?
  • Does addition make sense?
  • Does subtraction makes sense?

Teacher Moves: Selecting and Sequencing

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

Look for examples where students verbalize or right about using addition or subtraction number sentences to represent a situation. Make sure students are also discussing how addition is commutative and subtraction is not.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Compare Thinking

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

Have groups share their thinking about the different grade levels money raising plans in the Initial Challenge. Discuss the similarities and differences in how to approach profit and loss.

Have teams share their results from thinking about the What If Situations.

Teacher Moves: Chalk Talk

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

When discussing the Initial Challenge bring out how students are making sense of profit and loss. Bring out how they record their thinking using integers.

Suggested Questions

  • In the Initial Challenge, how does the advertising money impact profit or loss?
  • How does the price for purchasing smoothie bars from a distributor/supplies or a car wash/price or to create a digital recording impact profit or loss?
  • How did you record your thinking for the 6th grade/7th grade or 8th grade fundraising efforts?

Have students share their strategies for solving the equations in What If Situation C. Many students will find the answers mentally. Help them to verbalize their thinking and show this work using symbols. It is important for the teacher to take the student thinking and have them or the teacher illustrate it using symbols.

As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

investigations.title: CR Investigation 3 Multiplying and Dividing Rational Numbers

problems.title: CR 3.1 The Game of Relay Numbers
problems.subtitle: Multiplication Patterns with Rational Numbers

text:
Problem 3.1 The Number Relay Race Game: Multiplication Patterns with Rational Numbers

The Problem starts with a Number Relay Race in which runners are running on a number line that goes from -50 to +50. This race gives students practice in “reading” number lines that extend from positive to negative numbers. In the Initial Challenge students build on this experience to move to understanding multiplication with positive and negative integers. The What If Situations will look at the patterns in multiplying integers so that students will be able to describe an algorithm for multiplying integers.

NWDYK

Describe an algorithm for multiplying positive and negative rational numbers. How can you predict whether the sign of a product of two rational numbers is positive, negative, or zero?

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Analysis/Synthesis
Key Terms

Materials

Learning Aid: Situation A Cards

Learning Aid: Number Lines

Learning Aid: Chip Boards OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Two Color Chips OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Teaching Aid 3.1: Multiplication Patterns

Pacing

2 Days

Groups

2-3 students

A #1-2

C #12-14

E #21

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

Students may need help visualizing the team running along a number line that extends from -50 to 50.

Teacher Moves: Portrayal, Language

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Explain the context of the Number Relay Race. Having students act out the idea of going forward and backward in time and in direction of positive and negative can help students before they begin the Initial Challenge.

  • Students are asked to write number sentences for situations. It is important that they do this in order to make sense of what happens when you multiply different combinations of integers. Be sure to have students describe what each of the numbers represents in the problem.

Note: Stopping after What If Situation A and summarizing students’ thoughts before going to the rest of the What If will give students the opportunity to sort out any misconceptions they have about multiplication of integers.

EXPLORE

Teacher Moves: Going Vertical

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

Having students stand up and work on a vertical surface during this problem can increase engagement and collaboration between students as they work out the multiplication algorithm.

Suggested Questions

Ask clarifying questions to make sure students understand the context.

  • What does 5 meters per second mean?
  • Which way is he/she running? Left, or right? Positive or negative?
  • What number sentence could you write to show where Hahn will be in 6 seconds if he is going to the right and passes the 0-point running 5 meters per second?
  • What do the 5 and the 6 stand for?
  • Suppose Hahn was running 5 meters per second to the left. How would this change the number sentence?

Remind students that they are looking for patterns with multiplying positive and negative integers.

  • Students may struggle with multiplying a negative by a negative. If so, suggest that they think about what each sentence is saying in the context of the relay race and what seems reasonable.

Teacher Moves: Language

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

As students encounter the different situations in this problem asking them to think about things use these generalizations to help them sort through the patterns: Describe an algorithm for multiplying two positive rational numbers; a positive rational number and a negative rational number; a negative rational number and a negative rational number.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Compare Thinking

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

Have students share the number sentences they have written for the various Number Relay Race situations.

Teacher Moves: Language

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

Suggested Questions

  • What number sentences did you write for Aurelia (and others) in the Initial Challenge?
  • What does the operation of multiplication mean?
  • Here you have a positive number times a negative number. Why is the result negative?
  • Why does it make sense that this means Tori is at a positive position on the racing field?

Use What If Situations B and C to bring the ideas together for the students.

  • In What If Situation C, the three equations involving multiplying a positive factor times a negative factor and result in a negative product. Is this always true? Does a positive factor multiplied by a negative factor always give a negative product? Explain why or why not.
  • In What If Situation C, when you multiplied two negative factors, what is the sign of the product when two negative factors are multiplied?

As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

Problem 3.2 Revisiting the Relay Race: Division of Rational Numbers

In the Initial Challenge students will use the context of the Number Relay Race to write division equations. The What If Situations will help students look for patterns and describe an algorithm for dividing rational numbers.

NWDYK

Describe an algorithm for dividing rational numbers. Describe how multiplication and division are related.

Arc of Learning

Rational Numbers: Analysis/Synthesis

Key Terms

Multiplicative Identity

Multiplicative Inverse

Materials

Learning Aid: Number Lines

Learning Aid: Chip Boards (with two color chips) OR digital drawing tool with chip stamps

Pacing

1 Day

Groups

Think-Pair-Share

A #3-6

C #15-16

E #22

Facilitating Discourse

LAUNCH

CONNECTING TO PRIOR KNOWLEDGE

Write 36 ÷ 4 = 9 on the board.

Suggested Questions

  • What does this sentence mean?
  • How are the operations of multiplication and division related?

Teacher Moves: Think-Pair-Share, Problem Solving Environment

PRESENTING THE CHALLENGE

Remind students of the Number Relay race from yesterday. Have students begin the problem independently and then work with a partner to complete it.

EXPLORE

Teacher Moves: Portrayal

PROVIDING FOR INDIVIDUAL NEEDS

As students work on the Problem, listen for the patterns they are noticing. For the Initial Challenge it might help to encourage some students to draw the number relay situation to visualize the context.

Suggested Questions

  • In What If Situation A, what do you notice about the signs of the numbers in each group?
  • Is there a multiplicative identity for multiplication and division of rational numbers? Explain.
  • Is there a multiplicative inverse for each rational number?
  • What patterns do you see in the groups of equations?

Teacher Moves: Selecting and Sequencing

PLANNING FOR THE SUMMARY

As you are circulating during the explore listening for how students are making sense of the signs for the quotients in the division sentences. Find examples of student work/conversations that will help students describe a division algorithm and the relationship between multiplication and division.

SUMMARIZE

Teacher Moves: Claim, Support, Question, Language

SOLUTIONS AND STRATEGIES

Have students display their solutions. If there are disagreements about any of the solutions, have students discuss their solutions and explain why they make sense.

Facilitate a conversation to help students generalize some rules for dividing positive and negative integers. Look for opportunities to talk about fact families and the relationship between multiplication and division.

MAKING THE MATHEMATICS EXPLICIT

Suggested Questions

  • What multiplication problems are related to this division problem?

Completely Rational Mathematical Reflection

The Mathematical Reflection provides an opportunity to discuss the goals of the Investigation. Students can pull together their reasoning from the Now What Do You Know questions to summarize their learning over the time.

Students can record their responses to the Mathematical Reflection to create a record of their current understandings of the big ideas of the Unit. The Mathematical Reflection can provide a self-assessment for students. Each student can have check points of their understanding of the mathematics after each Investigation.

Students can use the MR to consolidate their mathematical thinking, take notes, and provide evidence of what they know and can do.

A teacher can gain an understanding of student thinking during a discussion of the reflection question. Then one can assess individual understanding based on each student’s written work.

Example Strategies for Student Participation

A few creative strategies teachers use to encourage students' ownership of their learning.

Anchor Charts

After a discussion, chart the emerging understanding and post it in the classroom. This can be done on poster paper or electronically.

  • Work with students throughout the unit to reference, add to, or refine their understandings.
  • Note: For teachers who move classrooms or have multiple classes of the same grade level, create the chart in all classes, but keep just one represent all of your classes. Post this one in the room or bring it out when needed.

Note Organization

Some teachers use the Mathematical Reflections as an organizer for note taking during the Investigation.

  • As part of the Summarize of the Problems, students record key ideas to the Now What Do You Know? reflection questions on a separate paper.
  • At the close of the Investigation, students synthesize their notes into responses that summarize their emerging understandings of the ideas in the unit.

Word Bank

As a class, create a word bank of terms from the Investigation.

  • Have groups of students write 3 – 4 statements using the words from the bank.
  • After formatively assessing their statements, you may choose to have a class discussion to refine the statements.

Chalk Talk

With a chalk talk, your writing does “the talking” instead of talking aloud.

  • Post the question(s) on sheets of chart paper or on sections of your board
  • Small groups record responses while collaborating in “chalk talk” format
  • Students move to others’ work and add their thinking in the form of new ideas and connections

Final Reflection Presentation

Teachers sometimes use the MR after the last Investigation as a summary of students’ learning.

  • Students consolidate their learning from the Unit.
  • Teachers choose from various ways to present their ideas. Presentation choices might include creating a: Poster, Written Paper, PowerPoint/Prezi, Song/Rap, etc.

Partner Write

Students create a written response to the reflection question with a partner.

  • Students discuss the reflection question with a partner.
  • Students create and write a response with a partner.

SUMMARIZE

Student Responses

At the beginning of the year, students will need more collaboration to outline and summarize the important ideas. They may need examples of writing, diagrams, and/or justifications from other students to help build their vision of what is expected when answering a Mathematical Reflection. Early in the year you may want to start writing Mathematical Reflections as a whole group. Then as the year progresses, move to small groups, pairs, and finally individuals.

Each Investigation contributes to students’ conceptual understandings of the ideas in the Unit. Students’ explanations at the beginning of a Unit might be just forming. As you progress through the Unit, students can use the contexts, representation, and connections to express a more solid understanding. By the end of the Unit, students can create a complete picture of understanding.
